questions.text: Charles Darwin is best known as the author of "The Origin of Species." Which of the following is also his work?
questions.explanation:
The Descent of Man.

	Darwin, "Father of Evolution," published "Origin of Species" after his famous trip to the Galapagos Islands aboard "The Beagle." "Descent" continues his thoughts on evolution. Enormous impact on intellectual thought about the nature of man. "Worlds" is by Immanuel Velikovsky," "Aggression" is by Konrad Lorenz, and "Imperative" is by Robert Ardrey.

questions.text: Karl Marx enjoyed a lifelong relationship with this gentleman--and also co-authored some major works with him.
questions.explanation:
Friedrich Engels.

	Marx, key figure in socialism and communism, co-authored "Das Kapital" with Engels. The book had huge impact on political thought and in the longer term also in politics, too.

questions.text: Albert Einstein was a giant in physics. What was his relationship with America?
questions.correct: He became a U.S. citizen as an adult
options: He was born in the U.S.
He worked in the U.S., but never became a citizen
He wasn't  born in the U.S.,  but grew up there as a child
questions.explanation:
He became a U.S. citizen as an adult

	Einstein, best known for his "Theory of Relativity" (although he had much more to say in physics) was born and grew up abroad. He became a citizen of the U.S. in 1940--after the war in Europe had started, but before America entered it. Truly, he changed the face of the world.

questions.text: Leonardo Da Vinci's most famous painting may be "Mona Lisa." Who was she?
options: A woman with whom Da Vinci had a romantic relationship
questions.explanation:
The wife of a merchant.

	Da Vinci is always the first to come to mind whenever the phrase "renaissance man" is mentioned. A man of accomplishment in both art and science.

questions.text: Sigmund Freud wrote all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Beyond Freedom and Dignity.

	The most influential thinker of the twentieth century, Freud's vision touches therapy, abnormality, religion, anthropology, dreams, etc.(It has been said that all personality theory is a reaction to Freud.)B.F. Skinner wrote "Dignity."

questions.text: William Shakespeare wrote many plays. Which of the following plays is in debate as to whether he was its author?
questions.explanation:
Pericles.

	Universally acclaimed as the greatest writer of the English language, shakespeare was pre-eminent as both poet and playwright. It is unclear, however as to whether he is the author of "Pericles."

questions.text: Immanuel Kant is perhaps best known as the author of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Critique of Pure Reason.

	He was one of the great philosophers of all time. "Critique" is Kant's masterpiece. "Liberty" is by J.S. Mill, "Leviathan" is by Thomas Hobbes, "Zarathustra" is by Nietzsche.

questions.text: Ludwig Van Beethoven had a stormy life. Which of the following statements is true?
options: He married, but had numerous extra-marital affairs
questions.explanation:
He never married.

	Beethoven never married, but he had many turbulent relationships. A genius in music, haunted by deafness.

questions.text: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart had a tempestuous relationship with his father, Leopold. Which of the following accurately describes Leopold?
questions.explanation:
Composer.

	Leopold was a composer. In that regard, Mozart followed in his footsteps--and took the family talent to exalted heights. A great talent--dead at 35.

questions.text: Copernicus was a key figure in the history of science. When did he perform the majority of his work?
questions.explanation:
16th century.

	Copernicus lived from 1473-1543, so his mature thought occurred during the first half of the 16th century. The father of the heliocentric theory (with the sun at the center of the solar system), he was an early giant in modern scientific thought.
